description: The unripe fruit of banana plants, specifically cooking varieties often referred to as plantains. They are starchy, less sweet than ripe dessert bananas, and are typically cooked as a vegetable.
healthBenefits: Good source of complex carbohydrates, providing sustained energy.
Rich in Vitamin C, Vitamin B6, and Vitamin A.
High in potassium, which helps regulate blood pressure.
Contains resistant starch, beneficial for gut health.

potentialAllergies.name: Latex-Fruit Syndrome
potentialAllergies.details: Individuals allergic to latex may also react to bananas/plantains.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide: (Similar to dessert bananas)
1. Propagation: From suckers or corms.
2. Soil: Rich, fertile, well-drained soil. pH 5.5-7.0. Full sun.
3. Watering: Requires abundant water and humidity.
4. Harvesting: Harvested green and firm for culinary use as a vegetable. Size and maturity depend on variety and intended use.
growthDuration: 9-12 months from planting to first harvest of bunches.
sustainabilityTips: Store raw bananas/plantains at room temperature if you want them to ripen slightly, or in the refrigerator to slow ripening.
Peel before cooking. The flesh is firm and starchy.
Versatile: can be boiled, fried, baked, or mashed. Used to make chips, curries, and side dishes.
carbonFootprintInfo: Moderate, similar to dessert bananas, depending on transport (0.5-0.8 kg CO2e/kg).

staticRecipes.name: Raw Banana Fry (Vazhakkai Poriyal/Varuval)
staticRecipes.description: A simple South Indian stir-fry or shallow-fry of raw banana slices with spices.
ingredients: 1/2 tsp sambar powder or red chili powder (optional)
steps: Peel raw bananas and slice them into rounds or semi-circles. Keep them in water mixed with a little buttermilk or turmeric to prevent discoloration.
Heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds. When they splutter, add urad dal and dried red chilies. Sauté until dal turns golden.
Add asafoetida and curry leaves. Sauté for a few seconds.
Drain banana slices and add them to the pan. Add turmeric powder, sambar/chili powder (if using), and salt.

Stir well to coat. Cook on medium heat, stirring occasionally, for 10-15 minutes, or until bananas are tender and slightly crisp. For a crispier version (varuval), add more oil and cook longer until browned.
Serve hot as a side dish.

staticRecipes.name: Kele ke Kofte (Raw Banana Dumplings in Gravy)
staticRecipes.description: Soft dumplings made from mashed raw banana, served in a savory Indian gravy.
ingredients: For Koftas: 2 raw bananas (boiled, peeled, mashed), 2 tbsp gram flour (besan), 1/2 tsp ginger paste, salt, oil for frying
For Gravy: 1 onion (pureed), 2 tomatoes (pureed), 1 tsp ginger-garlic paste, 1/2 tsp turmeric, 1 tsp coriander powder, 1/2 tsp cumin powder, garam masala, salt, oil
steps: Koftas: Combine mashed raw banana, besan, ginger paste, and salt. Mix well to form a dough. Make small balls and deep fry until golden brown. Set aside.
Gravy: Heat oil. Sauté onion puree until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste. Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates.
Add all spice powders (turmeric, coriander, cumin, chili if using) and salt. Sauté for a minute.
Add about 1 cup of water and bring to a simmer. Adjust consistency as needed.
Gently add fried koftas to the gravy. Simmer for 5-7 minutes.
Sprinkle with garam masala. Serve hot with roti or rice.

staticRecipes.name: Raw Banana Chips (Plantain Chips)
staticRecipes.description: Crispy, savory chips made from thinly sliced raw bananas.
steps: Peel raw bananas. It's easiest to score the skin lengthwise in a few places and then peel it off.

Thinly slice the peeled bananas into rounds using a mandoline slicer or a sharp knife. For best results, slice directly into hot oil or keep slices in water with turmeric to prevent browning, then pat very dry before frying.
Heat oil in a deep pan or kadai for frying.
Carefully drop banana slices into hot oil in batches, without overcrowding. Fry on medium heat, stirring occasionally, until golden brown and crisp (about 3-5 minutes).
Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels.
While still warm, sprinkle with salt and optional chili powder. Toss to coat.
Let cool completely before storing in an airtight container. They will become crispier as they cool.
